ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:55): Like http://www.liquidx.net/plotkit/ ?
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (17:56): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: ah, that's more like it
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (17:57): or you could use svg :)
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:00): SVG almost detracts from canvas. Because you can use SVG for example instead of <canvas> in plotkit can't you? And probably in a lot of other use cases too
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:01): There are lots of cases where they can overlap
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:01): and some of those are nicer in canvas, and some are nicer in SVG
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:02): and other cases can only realistically be done in one or the other
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:03): ok an example for specific case
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:04): can SVG do animation? canvas can defn. do animation
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:04): canvas is somewhat supported in IE6 right? that SVG isn't?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:05): SVG can do declarative animation, and you can do scripted animation too
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:06): hmm, so there is no distinction between the two with animation
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:06): There's a nasty hack to get some support for some parts of <canvas> in IE, which it seems people are using successfully in practice
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:07): I don't think anyone does the same to make SVG work in IE
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:07): so +1 for canvas. kinda.d
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:08): i need IE6 on this macosx machine i have for testing

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:08): f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678: There is a distinction - e.g. SVG lets you animate a single object moving, whereas canvas requires you to repaint the entire screen whenever you change something

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:09): and SVG has annoying bugs in most implementations when you try doing something fancy, whereas canvas is more predictable since it has simple bugs instead of fancy bugs
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:10): so there is some talk about canvas3D
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:10): silly question: can SVG do 3D? :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:11): Canvas-3d is pretty much totally different to canvas-2d
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:11): (http://blog.vlad1.com/2007/11/26/canvas-3d-gl-power-web-style/ etc)
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:11): and so would SVG-3D I guess (if it exists?)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:12): SVG is just focussed on 2D, and doesn't make it easy to emulate 3D
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:12): There's stuff like X3D which is kind of analogous to SVG except 3D
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:12): http://apike.ca/prog_svg_threed.html
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:15): thinks if i could do a couple of ven diagrams showing 1) support in browsers 2) use cases it could accomplish
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (18:15): perhaps a little pointless as the future (support + features) is probably the most important elements in my mind.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:15): That cube appears to not work in either Opera or Firefox 2 :-(
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:17): From what I've seen, canvas-2d allows slightly more impressive 3D emulation, though obviously it's all useless compared to canvas-3d
